Hello, and welcome to the Morningstar series,
"Why Should I Invest With You?" I'm Emma Wall

11.text:
and I'm joined today by Hugh Yarrow, Co-Manager
of the Evenlode Income Fund.

16.text:
So, we've heard this week that Brexit really
does mean Brexit. And one of the things if

22.text:
we put the economic implications aside for
investors, is how the stock market has reacted

27.text:
since we had that vote to leave and that's
been that large-caps have really outperformed

33.text:
small and mid-sized companies. And because
of that those companies are looking more expensive

39.text:
now and I know that you have a screen to indicate
an investable universe for Evenlode Income.

45.text:
So, have you seen now those much larger companies
become too expensive to invest in?

50.text:
Well, I wouldn't want to generalize too much.
I think immediately after the Brexit vote

56.text:
there was a fairly sharp reaction, particularly
in mid-caps and particularly those that do

60.text:
have exposure to the U.K. domestic economy.
And we saw some good opportunities to add

66.text:
to existing holdings in the mid-cap sector,
but also a couple of new positions as well

72.text:
that we brought into the fund.
Having said that, a lot of those companies

76.text:
then actually recovered reasonably well. And
so, the sentiment towards mid-caps thus deteriorated,

83.text:
certainly not sort of desperately negative
and there's quite a lot of domestically-exposed

90.text:
companies in our investable universe, very
high-quality businesses, strong balance sheets,

95.text:
high free cash flows that we would be very
interested in investing in if sentiment did

100.text:
deteriorate further over the next few months
or over the next couple of years. So, we are

105.text:
keeping a watch on that.
In terms of large-cap stocks, I mean, I think

108.text:
part of the rally has very much been about
currency. Clearly, sterling has depreciated

114.text:
significantly and that's beneficial to the
multinationals in the FTSE 100. It's also

119.text:
partly been about the recovery in commodity
and oil prices, which is obviously a big sector

125.text:
of the FTSE 100, too. We continue to see some
good valuation opportunities in large-caps

131.text:
too, but it's very stock specific.
And will we expect that to continue, because

135.text:
of course Brexit is still quite an uncertain
concept. That uncertainty is part of the reason

141.text:
why sterling has devalued so much. So, 2017,
are you expecting it to be another year for

147.text:
large multinational companies?
Well, it's certainly a tailwind for them at

152.text:
the moment. And if currency stays where it
is today, then some of these companies saw

157.text:
some benefit to their earnings and cash flow
last year, but really that will come through

162.text:
more significantly in 2017. And I think it's
interesting from a dividend perspective. I

169.text:
think I said last year with you, it's very,
very mixed outlook and you've got a fundamental

173.text:
backdrop that's quite difficult. Economic
growth is quite low globally.

177.text:
Payout ratios have risen. And so, growth rates
generally across the market have slowed. But

182.text:
in the U.K., you are now having this offsetting
factor of weak sterling being beneficial to

188.text:
earnings and therefore, a slightly better
outlook for dividends. So, there was modest

192.text:
growth last year. It would have been a decline
if it hadn't been for sterling. This year

196.text:
again a difficult backdrop but it will be
helped by the currency effect.

201.text:
You've alluded to there that the fact that
we can't sort of lump all large-caps and all

205.text:
small and mid into a particular bucket that
says, has done well, will do well, hasn't

210.text:
do well, won't do well. So, within those,
sort of, cap scale where are you seeing the

216.text:
opportunities? Is it particular sectors?
I think – I mean, we always focus on strong

222.text:
balance sheets and high free cash flow generation,
businesses that can self-fund their own organic

229.text:
investment. But I think we're particularly
conscious of that in the current market. I

233.text:
think particularly with balance sheet strength,
debt is very cheap, borrowing has crept up

240.text:
at the market level and I think it's partly
a function of the low – generally low-growth

246.text:
economic environment. Businesses are tempted
to use debt to buy back shares or make acquisitions

251.text:
to offset low growth.
But clearly, that does come with some risk.

256.text:
And so, where we've seen good opportunities
to buy businesses on attractive valuations,

261.text:
attractive dividends, but crucially where
the balance sheets are strong and the free

265.text:
cash flow is healthy. That's really where
we've been focusing. And that's a fairly disparate

270.text:
group of stocks, but that's definitely a trend
that they all share, a characteristic that

275.text:
they all share.
Hugh, thank you very much.

276.text:
No problem.
This is Emma Wall for Morningstar. Thank you
